Situation1: The meeting will cover key project updates that won’t be summarized elsewhere.
Situation2: They have been scheduled to chant a portion during the service.
Story: I stared at my calendar, heart pounding. The team meeting was set for Friday afternoon, the same time as Shabbat services. My manager had emphasized how crucial this meeting was—project updates, new assignments, things that wouldn’t be recapped later. Missing it meant falling behind, maybe even letting my team down. But this Friday, I wasn’t just attending synagogue; I was scheduled to chant a Torah portion. The rabbi and my community were counting on me. I’d practiced for weeks, and my family was proud. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in. My colleagues expected me to be present, engaged, a reliable part of the team. My faith and community expected me to honor my commitment, to show up and lead. I could feel the tension twisting inside me, the fear of disappointing someone no matter what I chose. I sat at my desk, torn, wishing I could be in two places at once.
